<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/playful-taurus';
	}
</script>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Unit 42"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/unit42/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="Advanced Persistent Threat,backdoor,China,Compromise,Iran,Playful Taurus,Turian"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/PA-Unit42-TAC-PlayfulTaurus_-Landscape.jpg"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Chinese Playful Taurus Activity in Iran","name":"Chinese Playful Taurus Activity in Iran","description":"Chinese APT Playful Taurus is using a new backdoor named Turian. Analysis suggests several Iranian government networks have likely been compromised.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/playful-taurus\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/playful-taurus\/","datePublished":"January 18, 2023","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nPlayful Taurus, also known as APT15, BackdoorDiplomacy, Vixen Panda, KeChang and NICKEL, is a Chinese advanced persistent threat group that routinely conducts cyber espionage campaigns. The group has been active since at least 2010 and has historically targeted government and diplomatic entities across North and South America, Africa and the Middle East.\r\n\r\nIn June 2021, ESET reported that this group had upgraded their tool kit to include a new backdoor called Turian. This backdoor remains under active development and we assess that it is used exclusively by Playful Taurus actors. Following the evolution of this capability, we recently identified new variants of this backdoor as well as new command and control infrastructure. Analysis of both the samples and connections to the malicious infrastructure suggests that several Iranian government networks have likely been compromised by Playful Taurus.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protections from the threats described in this blog through Advanced URL Filtering, DNS Security, Cortex XDR and WildFire malware analysis.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNames for Threat Actor Group Discussed\r\nPlayful Taurus, APT15, BackdoorDiplomacy, Vixen Panda, NICKEL\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPlayful Taurus Infrastructure\r\nIn 2021, the domain vpnkerio[.]com was identified as part of a Playful Taurus campaign targeting diplomatic entities and telecommunications companies across Africa and the Middle East. Since then, this domain and its associated subdomains have shifted hosting to several new IP addresses. Notably, several of the subdomains currently resolve to 152.32.181[.]16.\r\n\r\nAnalyzing this IP, we identified an expired X.509 certificate that appeared to be associated with Senegal\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA), CN=diplosen.gouv[.]sn.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSuspected Playful Taurus X509 Certificate\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA-1\r\ncfd9884511f2b5171c00570da837c31094e2ec72\r\n\r\n\r\nIssued\r\n2020-04-23\r\n\r\n\r\nExpires\r\n2021-04-29\r\n\r\n\r\nCommon Name\r\ndiplosen.gouv[.]sn\r\n\r\n\r\nOrganization Name\r\nDigiCert, Inc.\r\n\r\n\r\nSSL Version\r\n3\r\n\r\n\r\nLocality\r\nDakar\r\n\r\n\r\nCountry\r\nSN\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Suspected Playful Taurus certificate.\r\nDespite expiring in April 2021, this certificate continued to be associated with recent infrastructure.\u00a0For example, this certificate was first observed on 152.32.181[.]16 in April 2022, a full year after it had expired. Coincidentally, that same month, subdomains for vpnkerio[.]com began resolving to this IP.\r\nExploring all IP associations with this certificate, we found that this certificate was initially associated with what we assess is likely legitimate Senegal government infrastructure. This association remained consistent until the expiration of the certificate in April 2021. Following its expiration, this certificate has been associated with nine different IP addresses. Eight of those nine IPs have hosted Playful Taurus domains.\r\nObserved Activity\r\nMonitoring connections to the malicious infrastructure, we observed the following four Iranian organizations attempting to connect to 152.32.181[.]16 between July and late December 2022.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIranian Connections to Playful Taurus Infrastructure\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIP Address\r\nOrganization\r\n\r\n\r\n109.201.27[.]66\r\nIranian Government Infrastructure\r\n\r\n\r\n185.4.17[.]10\r\nForeign Ministry of Iran Infrastructure\r\n\r\n\r\n37.156.28[.]101\r\n37.156.29[.]172\r\nSuspected Iranian Government Infrastructure\r\n\r\n\r\n31.47.62[.]201\r\nIranian Natural Resource Organization\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. Iranian connections to Playful Taurus infrastructure.\r\nThe sustained daily nature of these connections to Playful Taurus controlled infrastructure suggests a likely compromise of these networks. Moreover, these targets also fit historical targeting patterns by the group.\r\nInside the Wire\r\nWhile researching the Iranian infrastructure in Table 2, we found that the first IP (109.201.27[.]66) hosted what appears to be a legitimate Foreign Ministry of Iran domain (pro.mfa[.]ir) between May and November 2019. This IP also resides on a netblock that hosts other Iranian government domains.\r\n\r\nHowever, since September 2021, this IP has hosted the domain mfaantivirus[.]xyz. The use of the .xyz top level domain (TLD) seems odd for an IP and netblock that hosts legitimate Iranian government domains.\r\n\r\nThe registration record for mfaantivirus[.]xyz shows that it was registered by an organization that has only registered eight other domains. Three of those domains, including mfaantivirus[.]xyz, stand out for being hosted on Iranian government netblocks. The two additional domains hosted on Iranian government infrastructure are as follows.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRegistration Organization Overlap\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIP\r\nDomain\r\nOwner\r\n\r\n\r\n109.201.27[.]67\r\npfs1010[.]xyz\r\nForeign Ministry of Iran\r\n\r\nReverse PTR: cp.econsular[.]ir\r\n\r\n\r\n109.201.19[.]184\r\npfs1010[.]com\r\nForeign Ministry of Iran\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 3. Domains sharing a registering organization with mfaantivirus[.]xyz.\r\nThe first IP in Table 3 contains a reverse DNS pointer to cp.econsular[.]ir, and the second IP\u2019s netname is \u201cForeign Ministry of Iran.\u201d This suggests that both are affiliated with the Iranian government.\r\n\r\nThat said, further analysis of these IPs revealed associations with two X.509 certificates. The earliest certificate appears to be related to pfSense and was only associated with these IPs for a single day in August 2019. This leads us to believe that the two pfs1010.* domains are made to resemble pfSense firewalls. The use of the domain name mfaantivirus[.]xyz loosely fits the security theme as well.\r\n\r\nThe second certificate associated with the IPs in Table 3 is a self-signed certificate with a common name of www.netgate[.]com. Netgate is the doing business as (DBA) name for Rubicon Communications, who developed pfSense \u2013 again sticking with the pfSense theme. Below is the information associated with that certificate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNetgate X.509 Certificate\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA-1\r\n1cf1985aec3dd1f7040d8e9913d9286a52243aca\r\n\r\n\r\nIssued\r\n2022-04-21\r\n\r\n\r\nExpires\r\n2032-04-18\r\n\r\n\r\nCommon Name\r\nwww.netgate[.]com\r\n\r\n\r\nOrganization Name\r\nnetgate\r\n\r\n\r\nSSL Version\r\n1\r\n\r\n\r\nLocality\r\nNew York\r\n\r\n\r\nState\/Province\r\nNew York\r\n\r\n\r\nCountry\r\nUnited States\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 4. Second suspected Playful Taurus certificate.\r\nThere are five additional malicious IPs associated with this certificate, but the two we wish to highlight are the following.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nX509 Certificate Two - IP Associations\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIP\r\nOwner\r\n\r\n\r\n151.248.24[.]251\r\nNYNEX satellite OHG\r\n\r\nPrevious Cert: portal-Share.mfa[.]new\r\n\r\n\r\n158.247.222[.]6\r\nConstant Company VPS\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 5. X509 certificate two \u2013 IP associations.\r\nThe first IP contains a historical certificate reference to portal-Share.mfa[.]new, which suggests an ambiguous \u201cMinistry of Foreign Affairs (MFA)\u201d nexus. The second is a virtual private server (VPS) owned by The Constant Company. This second IP (158.247.222[.]6) hosted the domain www[.]delldrivers[.]in from July 7, 2022 to Oct. 11, 2022. This domain is associated with a Turian backdoor sample.\r\n\r\nTying this all together, we identified Iranian government infrastructure establishing connections with a known Playful Taurus command and control (C2) server. Pivoting on one of the Iranian government IPs, we then identified additional infrastructure hosting certificates that overlap with a second Playful Taurus C2 server.\r\nTurian Backdoor\r\nAnalyzing the domain *.delldrivers[.]in resulted in the identification of the following sample of malware.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Details\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFilename\r\ndellux[.]exe\r\n\r\n\r\nCreation Time\r\n2022-06-27 01:25:26 UTC\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n67c911510e257b341be77bc2a88cedc99ace2af852f7825d9710016619875e80\r\n\r\n\r\nConnections\r\nupdate.delldrivers[.]in\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 6. File details for Turian sample.\r\nThis sample was uploaded to VirusTotal from submitters in Iran on Nov. 12 and 13, 2022. We further observed that these same submitters uploaded files and URLs that suggest a likely affiliation with Iran\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs.\r\nTechnical Analysis\r\nWe found that this sample is packed with VMProtect. However, the final payload is not virtualized and is ultimately unpacked into the .text, .data and .rdata sections of the payload. Unfortunately, VMProtect obfuscates all API calls within the sample. So whenever an API call is made, execution jumps to the .vmp0 section to resolve the import and execute it.\r\n\r\nWhile the functionality of the sample becomes increasingly difficult to analyze due to the API obfuscation, the strings within the unpacked .data section provide a useful pivot point for identifying additional samples that contain the same functionality but are not packed with VMProtect.\r\n\r\nAlongside the strings, the sample also contains a fairly unique XOR decryption function (shown in Figure 1). This is used to decrypt the embedded C2 server, update.delldrivers[.]in.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126625\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"215\"] Figure 1. Fairly unique decryption algorithm.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nA similar algorithm has been seen within the Neshta file infector, back in 2014. Data encrypted with this algorithm can be decrypted with the Python snippet shown in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126627\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"371\"] Figure 2. Python data decryptor.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nPivoting on the algorithm\u2019s byte pattern {69 D2 05 84 08 08 8A 1C 30 42 32 DA 88 1C 30} allows us to identify two additional malware samples.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Details\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFilename\r\nscm[.]exe\r\n\r\n\r\nType\r\nEXE\r\n\r\n\r\nCreation Time\r\n2022-04-28 02:56:26 UTC\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n8549c5bafbfad6c7127f9954d0e954f9550d9730ec2e06d6918c050bf3cb19c3\r\n\r\n\r\nConnections\r\nscm.oracleapps[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 7. File details of the first sample located via pivoting on algorithm byte pattern.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Details\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nType\r\nDLL\r\n\r\n\r\nCreation Time\r\n2022-06-18 14:43:13 UTC\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nad22f4731ab228a8b63510a3ab6c1de5760182a7fe9ff98a8e9919b0cf100c58\r\n\r\n\r\nConnections\r\nupdate.adboeonline[.]net\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 8. File details of the second sample located via pivoting on algorithm byte pattern.\r\n\r\nThe Turian Link\r\nAside from the C2 infrastructure being very similar in naming convention, comparing the code bases of these samples to the unpacked VMProtect sample indicates clear overlap between the functionality.\r\n\r\nDue to the almost identical code base, we opted to focus our analysis on the executable, rather than the DLL. Before doing so, we had a look at the DLL and noticed several cleartext strings.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSearching for samples with similar strings, we identified two additional samples.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Details\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nType\r\nDLL\r\n\r\n\r\nCreation Time\r\n2022-04-28 02:56:26 UTC\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n5bb99755924ccb6882fc0bdedb07a482313daeaaa449272dc291566cd1208ed5\r\n\r\n\r\nConnections\r\n127.0.0.1\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 9. File details of the first sample located via pivoting on registry strings.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Details\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nType\r\nx64 DLL\r\n\r\n\r\nCreation Time\r\n2022-06-18 14:43:13 UTC\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n6828b5ec8111e69a0174ec14a2563df151559c3e9247ef55aeaaf8c11ef88bfa\r\n\r\n\r\nConnections\r\nmail.indiarailways[.]net\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 10. File details of the second sample located via pivoting on registry strings.\r\nThese samples have been tagged in VirusTotal as being APT_MAL_LNX_Turian_Jun21_1, which is a Linux version of the Turian backdoor. However, these samples are clearly not for Linux systems. This tag did point us toward previous reporting on the Turian\/Quarian backdoors, which established a link between our dellux.exe sample and Turian.\r\nAn Updated Variant\r\nKey differences between our samples and the previously documented Turian samples indicated that we were likely looking at a newer version, with some additional obfuscation and a modified network protocol.\r\n\r\nThe first key difference was the C2 decryption algorithm. In prior Turian samples, the C2s were decrypted with an XOR against a hard coded byte, such as 0xA9.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhereas in the dellux.exe sample, the algorithm has clearly been updated.\r\n\r\nAdditionally, the network protocol in use by Turian and Quarian backdoors has historically been very distinct, especially during the initial key exchange. In this variant, the network protocol has been altered to instead make use of the Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI).\r\n\r\nOn startup, Turian will retrieve a pointer to the SSPI Dispatch Table via a call to InitSecurityInterfaceA(), before calling AcquireCredentialsHandleA(). A socket is then opened to the remote C2, using standard Winsock API, with connect() being called to establish a connection.\r\n\r\nOnce a connection has been made, Turian then performs an SSL handshake with the C2. This is done through a call to InitializeSecurityContextA(), which will return a token to send to the C2 server.\r\n\r\nOnce sent, Turian waits for a 5 byte response (the SSL\/TLS record header). This response contains the length of data also to be received from the C2 server, after the initial header. The remaining data is then passed into another call to InitializeSecurityContextA(), before returning. At this point, the handshake has been successful and secure communications can begin.\r\n\r\nAll packets sent to the C2 server are encrypted using the EncryptMessage() API, but are also XORed with the key 0x56 beforehand. The same functionality is performed on received packets, with the data being decrypted with DecryptMessage(), followed by XORing with 0x56.\r\n\r\nThe updated backdoor offers fairly generic functionality, from updating the C2 to communicate with, to executing commands and spawning reverse shells. The main differences with this compared to other variants of Turian are the command IDs. Whereas before, the IDs started at 0x01 and followed an order, the IDs in this variant appear to be randomized.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCommands Table\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n0xBC5B\r\nClean up\r\n\r\n\r\n0xA8CB\r\nUpdate C2\r\n\r\n\r\n0x9D58\r\nExecute Command\r\n\r\n\r\n0x9A3C\r\nSpawn File Explorer Thread\r\n\r\n\r\n0x7C0D\r\n(Unknown)\r\n\r\n\r\n0x6394\r\nSet Flag\r\n\r\n\r\n0x74D2\r\n(Unknown)\r\n\r\n\r\n0x53A6\r\nGet System Info\r\n\r\n\r\n0x26CD\r\nSpawn Reverse Shell Thread\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 11. Updated Turian commands.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nPlayful Taurus continues to evolve their tactics and their tooling. Recent upgrades to the Turian backdoor and new C2 infrastructure suggest that these actors continue to see success during their cyber espionage campaigns. Our analysis of the samples and connections to the malicious infrastructure suggest that Iranian government networks have likely been compromised. At the same time, we would also caution that Playful Taurus routinely deploys the same tactics and techniques against other government and diplomatic entities across North and South America, Africa and the Middle East.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nProtections and Mitigations\r\nFor Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group:\r\n\r\n \tWildFire\u00a0cloud-based threat analysis service accurately identifies the Turian malware described in this blog as malicious.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering\u00a0and\u00a0DNS Security\u00a0identify domains associated with Playful Taurus as malicious.\r\n \tCortex XDR\u00a0prevents the execution of known malware samples as malicious. It also prevents the execution of Turian malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and the new in-memory shellcode protection released in Cortex 3.5.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the\u00a0Unit 42 Incident Response team\u00a0or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nInfrastructure\r\n\r\n152.32.181[.]16\r\n158.247.222[.]6\r\nvpnkerio[.]com\r\nupdate.delldrivers[.]in\r\nscm.oracleapps[.]org\r\nupdate.adboeonline[.]net\r\nmail.indiarailways[.]net\r\n\r\nPlayful <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/playful-taurus/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-126622-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Playful Taurus, also known as APT15, BackdoorDiplomacy, Vixen Panda, KeChang and NICKEL, is a Chinese advanced persistent threat group that routinely conducts cyber espionage campaigns. The group has been active since at least 2010 and has historically targeted government and diplomatic entities across North and South America, Africa and the Middle East.</p>
<p>In June 2021, ESET <a href="https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading-quarian-turian/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reported</a> that this group had upgraded their tool kit to include a new backdoor called Turian. This backdoor remains under active development and we assess that it is used exclusively by Playful Taurus actors. Following the evolution of this capability, we recently identified new variants of this backdoor as well as new command and control infrastructure. Analysis of both the samples and connections to the malicious infrastructure suggests that several Iranian government networks have likely been compromised by Playful Taurus.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from the threats described in this blog through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> malware analysis.</p>
<table style="width: 92.0506%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 49.0789%;"><b>Names for Threat Actor Group Discussed</b></td>
<td style="width: 95.8893%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Playful Taurus, APT15, BackdoorDiplomacy, Vixen Panda, NICKEL</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_5585fmkn19cf"></a>Playful Taurus Infrastructure</h2>
<p>In 2021, the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vpnkerio[.]com</span> was <a href="https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading-quarian-turian/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">identified</a> as part of a Playful Taurus campaign targeting diplomatic entities and telecommunications companies across Africa and the Middle East. Since then, this domain and its associated subdomains have shifted hosting to several new IP addresses. Notably, several of the subdomains currently resolve to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.32.181[.]16</span>.</p>
<p>Analyzing this IP, we identified an expired <a href="https://sectigo.com/resource-library/what-is-x509-certificate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">X.509 certificate</a> that appeared to be associated with Senegal’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA), <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CN=diplosen.gouv[.]sn</span>.</p>
<table style="width: 48.5974%; height: 321px;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 111.91%; height: 56px;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>Suspected Playful Taurus X509 Certificate</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 25px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 25px;"><b>SHA-1</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 25px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cfd9884511f2b5171c00570da837c31094e2ec72</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 24px;"><b>Issued</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 24px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2020-04-23</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 24px;"><b>Expires</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 24px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2021-04-29</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 48px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 48px;"><b>Common Name</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 48px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">diplosen.gouv[.]sn</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 48px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 48px;"><b>Organization Name</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 48px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DigiCert, Inc.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 24px;"><b>SSL Version</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 24px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 24px;"><b>Locality</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 24px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dakar</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 33.239%; height: 24px;"><b>Country</b></td>
<td style="width: 78.6712%; height: 24px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SN</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 1. Suspected Playful Taurus certificate.</em></span></p>
<p class="p1">Despite expiring in April 2021, this certificate continued to be associated with recent infrastructure. For example, this certificate was first observed on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.32.181[.]16</span> in April 2022, a full year after it had expired. Coincidentally, that same month, subdomains for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vpnkerio[.]com</span> began resolving to this IP.</p>
<p>Exploring all IP associations with this certificate, we found that this certificate was initially associated with what we assess is likely legitimate Senegal government infrastructure. This association remained consistent until the expiration of the certificate in April 2021. Following its expiration, this certificate has been associated with nine different IP addresses. Eight of those nine IPs have hosted Playful Taurus domains.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_dfigbgbqzm5d"></a>Observed Activity</h2>
<p>Monitoring connections to the malicious infrastructure, we observed the following four Iranian organizations attempting to connect to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.32.181[.]16</span> between July and late December 2022.</p>
<table style="width: 59.2314%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 87.1362%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>Iranian Connections to Playful Taurus Infrastructure</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.5366%;"><b>IP Address</b></td>
<td style="width: 55.5996%;"><b>Organization</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.5366%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">109.201.27[.]66</span></td>
<td style="width: 55.5996%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Iranian Government Infrastructure</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.5366%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.4.17[.]10</span></td>
<td style="width: 55.5996%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Foreign Ministry of Iran Infrastructure</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.5366%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">37.156.28[.]101</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">37.156.29[.]172</span></span></td>
<td style="width: 55.5996%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Suspected Iranian Government Infrastructure</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.5366%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">31.47.62[.]201</span></td>
<td style="width: 55.5996%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Iranian Natural Resource Organization</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 2. Iranian connections to Playful Taurus infrastructure.</em></span></p>
<p>The sustained daily nature of these connections to Playful Taurus controlled infrastructure suggests a likely compromise of these networks. Moreover, these targets also fit historical targeting patterns by the group.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126622-_tu5pyqvu4hwd"></a><strong>Inside the Wire</strong></h3>
<p>While researching the Iranian infrastructure in Table 2, we found that the first IP (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">109.201.27[.]66</span>) hosted what appears to be a legitimate Foreign Ministry of Iran domain (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pro.mfa[.]ir</span>) between May and November 2019. This IP also resides on a netblock that hosts other Iranian government domains.</p>
<p>However, since September 2021, this IP has hosted the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mfaantivirus[.]xyz</span>. The use of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.xyz</span> top level domain (TLD) seems odd for an IP and netblock that hosts legitimate Iranian government domains.</p>
<p>The registration record for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mfaantivirus[.]xyz</span> shows that it was registered by an organization that has only registered eight other domains. Three of those domains, including <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mfaantivirus[.]xyz</span>, stand out for being hosted on Iranian government netblocks. The two additional domains hosted on Iranian government infrastructure are as follows.</p>
<table style="width: 66.0559%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 161.663%;" colspan="3">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>Registration Organization Overlap</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.6618%; text-align: center;"><b>IP</b></td>
<td style="width: 25.1172%; text-align: center;"><b>Domain</b></td>
<td style="width: 104.884%; text-align: center;"><b>Owner</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.6618%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">109.201.27[.]67</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.1172%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pfs1010[.]xyz</span></td>
<td style="width: 104.884%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Foreign Ministry of Iran</span></p>
<p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Reverse PTR: </span></i><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">cp.econsular[.]ir</span></i></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 31.6618%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">109.201.19[.]184</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.1172%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pfs1010[.]com</span></td>
<td style="width: 104.884%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Foreign Ministry of Iran</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;">Table 3. Domains sharing a registering organization with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mfaantivirus[.]xyz</span>.</span></p>
<p>The first IP in Table 3 contains a reverse DNS pointer to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cp.econsular[.]ir</span>, and the second IP’s netname is “Foreign Ministry of Iran.” This suggests that both are affiliated with the Iranian government.</p>
<p>That said, further analysis of these IPs revealed associations with two X.509 certificates. The earliest certificate appears to be related to pfSense and was only associated with these IPs for a single day in August 2019. This leads us to believe that the two <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pfs1010.*</span> domains are made to resemble pfSense firewalls. The use of the domain name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mfaantivirus[.]xyz</span> loosely fits the security theme as well.</p>
<p>The second certificate associated with the IPs in Table 3 is a self-signed certificate with a common name of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.netgate[.]com</span>. Netgate is the doing business as (DBA) name for Rubicon Communications, who developed pfSense – again sticking with the pfSense theme. Below is the information associated with that certificate.</p>
<table style="width: 60.2194%; height: 609px;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 69.3511%; height: 56px;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>Netgate X.509 Certificate</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 57px;"><b>SHA-1</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1cf1985aec3dd1f7040d8e9913d9286a52243aca</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>Issued</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-04-21</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>Expires</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2032-04-18</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 80px;"><b>Common Name</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.netgate[.]com</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 80px;"><b>Organization Name</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">netgate</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>SSL Version</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">1</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>Locality</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">New York</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>State/Province</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">New York</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 19.6442%; height: 56px;"><b>Country</b></td>
<td style="width: 49.7069%; height: 56px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">United States</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;">Table 4. Second suspected Playful Taurus certificate.</span></p>
<p>There are five additional malicious IPs associated with this certificate, but the two we wish to highlight are the following.</p>
<table style="width: 52.3646%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 149.457%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>X509 Certificate Two - IP Associations</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 42.9481%; text-align: center;"><b>IP</b></td>
<td style="width: 106.508%; text-align: center;"><b>Owner</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 42.9481%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">151.248.24[.]251</span></td>
<td style="width: 106.508%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">NYNEX satellite OHG</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Previous Cert: </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">portal-Share.mfa[.]new</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 42.9481%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">158.247.222[.]6</span></td>
<td style="width: 106.508%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Constant Company VPS</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;">Table 5. X509 certificate two – IP associations.</span></p>
<p>The first IP contains a historical certificate reference to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">portal-Share.mfa[.]new</span>, which suggests an ambiguous “Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA)” nexus. The second is a virtual private server (VPS) owned by The Constant Company. This second IP (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">158.247.222[.]6</span>) hosted the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www[.]delldrivers[.]in</span> from July 7, 2022 to Oct. 11, 2022. This domain is associated with a Turian backdoor sample.</p>
<p>Tying this all together, we identified Iranian government infrastructure establishing connections with a known Playful Taurus command and control (C2) server. Pivoting on one of the Iranian government IPs, we then identified additional infrastructure hosting certificates that overlap with a second Playful Taurus C2 server.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_fjbdlhc3n6a1"></a>Turian Backdoor</h2>
<p>Analyzing the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">*.delldrivers[.]in</span> resulted in the identification of the following sample of malware.</p>
<table style="width: 659px;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 659px;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>File Details</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 122px;"><b>Filename</b></td>
<td style="width: 537px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dellux[.]exe</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 122px;"><b>Creation Time</b></td>
<td style="width: 537px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-06-27 01:25:26 UTC</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 122px;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 537px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">67c911510e257b341be77bc2a88cedc99ace2af852f7825d9710016619875e80</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 122px;"><b>Connections</b></td>
<td style="width: 537px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.delldrivers[.]in</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 10pt;">Table 6. File details for Turian sample.</span></p>
<p>This sample was uploaded to VirusTotal from submitters in Iran on Nov. 12 and 13, 2022. We further observed that these same submitters uploaded files and URLs that suggest a likely affiliation with Iran’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126622-_brrfil9tp0g2"></a><strong>Technical Analysis</strong></h3>
<p>We found that this sample is packed with <a href="https://vmpsoft.com/">VMProtect</a>. However, the final payload is not virtualized and is ultimately unpacked into the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.text</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.data</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.rdata</span> sections of the payload. Unfortunately, VMProtect obfuscates all API calls within the sample. So whenever an API call is made, execution jumps to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.vmp0</span> section to resolve the import and execute it.</p>
<p>While the functionality of the sample becomes increasingly difficult to analyze due to the API obfuscation, the strings within the unpacked <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.data</span> section provide a useful pivot point for identifying additional samples that contain the same functionality but are not packed with VMProtect.</p>
<p>Alongside the strings, the sample also contains a fairly unique XOR decryption function (shown in Figure 1). This is used to decrypt the embedded C2 server, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.delldrivers[.]in</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126625" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126625" style="width: 215px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126625" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126622-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a screenshot of many lines of code showing the XOR unique decryption algorithm. " width="215" height="209" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126625" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Fairly unique decryption algorithm.</figcaption></figure>
<p>A similar algorithm has been seen within the <a href="https://www.virusbulletin.com/virusbulletin/2014/08/bird-s-nest">Neshta file infector</a>, back in 2014. Data encrypted with this algorithm can be decrypted with the Python snippet shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126627" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126627" style="width: 371px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126627" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126622-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of many lines of Python code that could be used to decrypt an algorithm associated with the Neshta file infector. " width="371" height="169" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126627" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Python data decryptor.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Pivoting on the algorithm’s byte pattern <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">{69 D2 05 84 08 08 8A 1C 30 42 32 DA 88 1C 30}</span> allows us to identify two additional malware samples.</p>
<table style="width: 74.6417%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 119.771%;" colspan="2" align="center">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>File Details</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 20.7206%;"><b>Filename</b></td>
<td style="width: 99.0503%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">scm[.]exe</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 20.7206%;"><b>Type</b></td>
<td style="width: 99.0503%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EXE</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 20.7206%;"><b>Creation Time</b></td>
<td style="width: 99.0503%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-04-28 02:56:26 UTC</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 20.7206%;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 99.0503%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8549c5bafbfad6c7127f9954d0e954f9550d9730ec2e06d6918c050bf3cb19c3</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 20.7206%;"><b>Connections</b></td>
<td style="width: 99.0503%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">scm.oracleapps[.]org</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;">Table 7. File details of the first sample located via pivoting on algorithm byte pattern.</span></p>
<table style="width: 75.516%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 52.2635%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>File Details</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.7673%;"><b>Type</b></td>
<td style="width: 34.4962%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DLL</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.7673%;"><b>Creation Time</b></td>
<td style="width: 34.4962%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-06-18 14:43:13 UTC</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.7673%;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 34.4962%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ad22f4731ab228a8b63510a3ab6c1de5760182a7fe9ff98a8e9919b0cf100c58</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.7673%;"><b>Connections</b></td>
<td style="width: 34.4962%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.adboeonline[.]net</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;">Table 8. File details of the second sample located via pivoting on algorithm byte pattern.</span></p>
<h3><a id="post-126622-_9g8tqsio8dql"></a><strong>The Turian Link</strong></h3>
<p>Aside from the C2 infrastructure being very similar in naming convention, comparing the code bases of these samples to the unpacked VMProtect sample indicates clear overlap between the functionality.</p>
<p>Due to the almost identical code base, we opted to focus our analysis on the executable, rather than the DLL. Before doing so, we had a look at the DLL and noticed several cleartext strings.</p>
<p><em><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126629" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126622-3.png" alt="Image 3 is is a screenshot of cleartext strings in the DLL. " width="625" height="134" /></em></p>
<p>Searching for samples with similar strings, we identified two additional samples.</p>
<table style="width: 75.5%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 108.014%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>File Details</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.4823%;"><b>Type</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.5314%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DLL</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.4823%;"><b>Creation Time</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.5314%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-04-28 02:56:26 UTC</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.4823%;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.5314%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5bb99755924ccb6882fc0bdedb07a482313daeaaa449272dc291566cd1208ed5</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.4823%;"><b>Connections</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.5314%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">127.0.0.1</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 10pt;">Table 9. File details of the first sample located via pivoting on registry strings.</span></p>
<table style="width: 75.5%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 107.221%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>File Details</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.1109%;"><b>Type</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.1098%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">x64 DLL</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.1109%;"><b>Creation Time</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.1098%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2022-06-18 14:43:13 UTC</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.1109%;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.1098%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6828b5ec8111e69a0174ec14a2563df151559c3e9247ef55aeaaf8c11ef88bfa</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 19.1109%;"><b>Connections</b></td>
<td style="width: 88.1098%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mail.indiarailways[.]net</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 10pt;">Table 10. File details of the second sample located via pivoting on registry strings.</span></p>
<p>These samples have been tagged in VirusTotal as being <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APT_MAL_LNX_Turian_Jun21_1</span>, which is a Linux version of the Turian backdoor. However, these samples are clearly not for Linux systems. This tag did point us toward previous reporting on the Turian/Quarian backdoors, which established a link between our <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dellux.exe</span> sample and Turian.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126622-_sert7axmryed"></a><strong>An Updated Variant</strong></h3>
<p>Key differences between our samples and the previously documented Turian samples indicated that we were likely looking at a newer version, with some additional obfuscation and a modified network protocol.</p>
<p>The first key difference was the C2 decryption algorithm. In prior Turian samples, the C2s were decrypted with an XOR against a hard coded byte, such as 0xA9.</p>
<p><em><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126631" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126622-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of 5 lines of code showing hardcoded byte 0xA9." width="497" height="113" /></em></p>
<p>Whereas in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dellux.exe</span> sample, the algorithm has clearly been updated.</p>
<p>Additionally, the network protocol in use by Turian and Quarian backdoors has historically been very distinct, especially during the initial key exchange. In this variant, the network protocol has been altered to instead make use of the Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI).</p>
<p>On startup, Turian will retrieve a pointer to the SSPI Dispatch Table via a call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">InitSecurityInterfaceA()</span>, before calling <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AcquireCredentialsHandleA()</span>. A socket is then opened to the remote C2, using standard Winsock API, with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">connect()</span> being called to establish a connection.</p>
<p>Once a connection has been made, Turian then performs an SSL handshake with the C2. This is done through a call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">InitializeSecurityContextA()</span>, which will return a token to send to the C2 server.</p>
<p>Once sent, Turian waits for a 5 byte response (the SSL/TLS record header). This response contains the length of data also to be received from the C2 server, after the initial header. The remaining data is then passed into another call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">InitializeSecurityContextA()</span>, before returning. At this point, the handshake has been successful and secure communications can begin.</p>
<p>All packets sent to the C2 server are encrypted using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">EncryptMessage()</span> API, but are also XORed with the key 0x56 beforehand. The same functionality is performed on received packets, with the data being decrypted with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DecryptMessage()</span>, followed by XORing with 0x56.</p>
<p>The updated backdoor offers fairly generic functionality, from updating the C2 to communicate with, to executing commands and spawning reverse shells. The main differences with this compared to other variants of Turian are the command IDs. Whereas before, the IDs started at 0x01 and followed an order, the IDs in this variant appear to be randomized.</p>
<table style="width: 59.4359%;" align="center">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 119.173%;" colspan="2">
<p style="text-align: center;"><b>Commands Table</b></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0xBC5B</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Clean up</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0xA8CB</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Update C2</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x9D58</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execute Command</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x9A3C</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Spawn File Explorer Thread</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x7C0D</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">(Unknown)</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x6394</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Set Flag</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x74D2</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">(Unknown)</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x53A6</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Get System Info</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.812%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x26CD</span></td>
<td style="width: 94.3609%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Spawn Reverse Shell Thread</span></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 10pt;">Table 11. Updated Turian commands.</span></p>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_f65uqufagf4w"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Playful Taurus continues to evolve their tactics and their tooling. Recent upgrades to the Turian backdoor and new C2 infrastructure suggest that these actors continue to see success during their cyber espionage campaigns. Our analysis of the samples and connections to the malicious infrastructure suggest that Iranian government networks have likely been compromised. At the same time, we would also caution that Playful Taurus routinely deploys the same tactics and techniques against other government and diplomatic entities across North and South America, Africa and the Middle East.</p>
<p><em>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the </em><a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org"><em>Cyber Threat Alliance</em></a><em>.</em></p>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> cloud-based threat analysis service accurately identifies the Turian malware described in this blog as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering </a>and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a> identify domains associated with Playful Taurus as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR </a>prevents the execution of known malware samples as malicious. It also prevents the execution of Turian malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and the new in-memory shellcode protection released in Cortex 3.5.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-126622-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>Infrastructure</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.32.181[.]16<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">158.247.222[.]6<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vpnkerio[.]com<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.delldrivers[.]in<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">scm.oracleapps[.]org<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">update.adboeonline[.]net<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mail.indiarailways[.]net</span></p>
<p>Playful Taurus Certificate SHA-1</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cfd9884511f2b5171c00570da837c31094e2ec72<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1cf1985aec3dd1f7040d8e9913d9286a52243aca</span></p>
<p>Turian Sample SHA-256</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">67c911510e257b341be77bc2a88cedc99ace2af852f7825d9710016619875e80<br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8549c5bafbfad6c7127f9954d0e954f9550d9730ec2e06d6918c050bf3cb19c3<br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5bb99755924ccb6882fc0bdedb07a482313daeaaa449272dc291566cd1208ed5<br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ad22f4731ab228a8b63510a3ab6c1de5760182a7fe9ff98a8e9919b0cf100c58<br />

<li><a href="https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/426/Bitdefender-PR-Whitepaper-BackdoorDiplomacy-creat6507-en-EN.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber-Espionage in the Middle East: Investigating a New BackdoorDiplomacy Threat Actor Campaign | Bitdefender</a></li>
</ul>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" title="North Korea" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:North Korea">North Korea</a>

				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remote-access-trojan/" title="Remote Access Trojan" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:Remote Access Trojan">Remote Access Trojan</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/finance/" title="Finance" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:Finance">Finance</a>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of Stately Taurus&#039; updated TTPs.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia">

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-protect-vpn-spoof-distributes-wikiloader/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="playful-taurus:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant">
